references.A68WIL02USGP: Wilson, D.E. 1968. Ecological distribution of the genus Peromyscus. The Southwestern Naturalist, 13(3):267-273.
references.A97VAN01USGP: Vander Wall, S.B. 1997. Dispersal of singleleaf pinon pine (Pinus monophylla) by seed-caching rodents. Journal of Mammalogy, 78(1):181-191.
references.A79ARM01USGP: Armstrong, D. M. 1979. Ecological distribution of rodents in Canyonlands National Park, Utah. Great Basin Nat. 39:199-205.
references.A69DOU01USGP: Douglas, C.L. 1969. Comparative ecology of pinyon mice and deer mice in Mesa Verde National Park, Colorado. University of Kansas Publications Museum of Natural History, 18(5):421-504.
references.A84OFA01USGP: O'Farrell, M. J. and W. A. Clark. 1984. Notes on the white-tailed antelope squirrel, Ammospermophilus leucurus, and the pinyon mouse, Peromyscus truei, in north central Nevada. Great Basin Nat. 44:428-430.
references.A87RIB01USGP: Ribble, D.O. and F.B. Samson. 1987. Microhabitat associations of small mammals in southeastern Colorado, with special emphasis on Peromyscus (Rodentia). The Southwestern Naturalist, 32(3):291-303.
references.A74BRA01USGP: Bradford, D.F. 1974. Water stress of free-living Peromyscus truei. Ecology, 55(6):1407-1414.
references.A73MAR01USGP: Marten, G.G. 1973. Time patterns of Peromyscus activity and their correlations with weather. Journal of Mammalogy, 54(1):169-188.
references.A55HOF01USGP: Hoffman, R.S. 1955. A Population-high for Peromyscus maniculatus. Journal of Mammalogy, 36(4):571-572.
references.A93CAR01USGP: Carraway, L.N., E. Yensen, B.J. Verts, and L.F. Alexander. 1993. Range extension and habitat of Peromyscus truei in Eastern Oregon. Northwestern Naturalist, 74(3):81-84.
references.A78LLE01USGP: Llewellyn, J.B. 1978. Reproductive patterns in Peromyscus truei truei in a pinyon-juniper woodland of western Nevada. Journal of Mammalogy, 59(2):449-451.
references.A64DEA01USGP: Deacon, J.E., W.G. Bradley, and K.M. Larsen. 1964. Ecological distribution of the mammals of Clark Canyon, Charleston Mountains, Nevada. Journal of Mammalogy, 45(3):397-409.
references.A98RIB01USGP: Ribble, D.O. and S. Stanley. 1998. Home ranges and social organization of syntopic Peromyscus boylii and P. truei. Journal of Mammalogy, 79(3):932-941.
references.A54QUA01USGP: Quast, J.C. 1954. Rodent habitat preferences on foothill pastures in California. Journal of Mammalogy, 35(4):515-521.
references.A63HAR01USGP: Harris, A. H. 1963. Ecological distribution of some vertebrates in the San Juan Basin, New Mexico. Mus. New Mexico Press, Papers in Anthrop. 8:40.
references.A97HAL01USGP: Hall, L.S. and M.L. Morrison. 1997. Den and relocation site characteristics and home ranges of Peromyscus truei in the White Mountains of California. Great Basin Naturalist, 57(2):124-130.
references.A10ROD01USGP: Rodhouse, T.J., R.P. Hirnyck, and R.G. Wright. 2010. Habitat selection of rodents along a pinon-juinper woodland-savannah gradient. Journal of Mammalogy, 91(2):447-457.
references.A11YAN01USGP: Yang, D-S., C.J. Conroy, and C. Moritz. 2011. Contrasting responses of Peromyscus mice of Yosemite National Park to recent climate change. Global Change Biology, 17:2559-2566.
references.A34BOR01USGP: Borell, A.E. and R. Ellis. 1934. Mammals of the Ruby Mountains region of north-eastern Nevada. Journal of Mammalogy, 15(1):12-44.

habitat_description:
Peromyscus truei primarily inhabits pinyon-juniper forest, woodland, shrubland, and savanna (Borell and Ellis, 1934; Deacon et al., 1964; Wilson, 1968; Douglas, 1969; Llewellyn, 1978; Armstrong, 1979; Ribble and Samson, 1987; Hall and Morrison, 1997; Rodhouse et al., 2010) and environments with either pinyon or juniper (Armstrong, 1979; Scheibe, 1984; Carraway et al., 1993; Scheibe and O’Farrell, 1995). 

Although Douglas (1969) found the species not to stray from pinyon and juniper habitats, O’Farrell and Clark (1984) captured them in shrublands of sagebrush and shadscale 21 km from the nearest pinyon or juniper habitat. Such a finding is supported by Hoffman (1955), Harris (1963), and Armstrong (1979).

Pinon deer mice can also be found in: rock outcrops (Quast, 1954; Wilson, 1968; Carraway et al., 1993); bristlecone pine woodlands (Burt, 1934; Deacon et al., 1964); and California coastal chaparral (Marten, 1973; Bradford, 1974).

While some studies have determined that the species avoids higher elevation conifer forests of fir, douglas-fir, spruce, or ponderosa pine (Wilson, 1968), Ribble and Stanley (1998) captured them within open woodland of ponderosa pine in New Mexico. Yang et al. (2011) noted the species’ recent migration to higher elevation woodlands of lodgepole pine and whitebark pine, in the Sierra Nevada.

P. truei avoids: grasslands (Wilson, 1968; Douglas, 1969); meadows and swales (Quast, 1954; Douglas, 1969); shrublands of rabbitbrush, mountain mahogany, and gray oak (Wilson, 1968); and low elevation desert scrub (Wilson, 1968).

The species’ elevation constraints are quite broad, with individuals documented from as low as 183 m (Moritz et al., 2008) to as high as 2896 m (Hoffman, 1955) in California.
